title: Tone & Mood in Writing
description: Learn to distinguish between tone and mood, and how writers create atmosphere in their works

questions.question: In literature, what does 'tone' refer to?
options: The background music in an audiobook
The volume at which a story is read aloud
The author's attitude toward the subject or audience

questions.question: What does 'mood' refer to in literature?
options: The emotional atmosphere or feeling that a work creates in the reader
The time of day in a story

questions.question: What is the key difference between tone and mood?
options: Tone is the author's attitude; mood is the feeling evoked in the reader
Mood is only found in poetry; tone is only in prose
Tone is about music; mood is about color

questions.question: Which word best describes a 'nostalgic' tone?
options: Wistful and longing for the past

questions.question: A story set in a dark, creaking old house during a thunderstorm is most likely creating which mood?
Which literary element most directly contributes to mood?
options: The font used in the book

questions.question: If an author writes with a 'sardonic' tone, the writing is:
Which of these best describes a 'whimsical' tone?
How can an author create a 'foreboding' mood?
options: By writing very short sentences only
By using dark imagery, ominous language, and hinting at danger

questions.question: What tone is conveyed when an author writes with detachment and objectivity, avoiding emotional language?
The opening of Charles Dickens' 'A Tale of Two Cities' sets a tone that is:
Which word describes a mood of peaceful contentment?
Word choice (diction) is important in establishing tone because:
options: The specific words an author chooses convey attitude and emotional weight
Diction has nothing to do with tone
Tone is determined only by the plot

questions.question: A 'didactic' tone in writing means the author is:
options: Writing in a stream of consciousness
Intending to teach a moral lesson or instruct

questions.question: Can the tone and mood of a story differ from each other?
options: No, the reader always feels exactly what the author intends
Yes, an author can have a humorous tone while creating a dark mood, for example
